FacilityName: West Shore Regional Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
General
    The West Shore Regional Water Treatment Plant (WSRWTP) is part of the Pennsylvania American Water (PAW) Mechanicsburg system.  The system serves approximately 32,000 customers in Cumberland and York Counties, west of the Susquehanna River near Harrisburg, PA.  The WSRWTP is a new facility designed with an initial treatment capacity of 12.0 MGD, with facilities designed for future expansion to 16.0 MGD.  Water from the Yellow Breeches Creek is pumped directly to the plant via a new raw water intake and pumping station.
    Treatment processes include oxidation of iron and manganese and organic matter, Superpulsator clarification, dual media filtration, and chloramine disinfection.  This plan addresses chlorine used in the treatment process.  The plant is operated 24 hours per day, all year.
    The water treatment plant includes a chlorine storage room, which contains up to twelve (12), one ton cylinders (24,000 pounds) of chlorine liquified under pressure, a hoist, scale(s), vacuum regulators and two gas detector/alarm units.  A chlorine feed room is located adjacent to this storage room and has a five pre and post chlorinators, as well as a gas detector/alarm unit.  The chlorination system uses remote vacuum-actuated feed lines and has vacuum regulators attached directly to the chlorine container gas valves, mitigating against high pressure gas releases through the chlorinator system.  Water treatment operators regularly check the room and its equipment, inventorying the rate of chlorine use and adjusting the feed rate as necessary.  A chlorine gas scrubber is provided to mitigate and neutralize leaks that may occur in the chlorine storage room.
Accidental Release Prevention
The West Shore Regional Water Treatment Plant?s accidental release prevention program is based upon the following elements:
1.    High level of training for the operators.
2.    Preventative maintenance program for equipment.
3.    Use of state of the art process and safety equipment.
4.    Use of accur

ate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the operators.
5.    Performance of a hazard review of the equipment and procedures.
6.    Implementation of an auditing and inspection program.
7.    Routine review of process safety.
Chemical specific prevention steps include availability of respirators, personal protection equipment (PPE), awareness of the hazards and toxic properties of chlorine, the presence of chlorine gas detectors, and the use of a chlorine scrubber.
Five Year Accident History
The facility is new, so there is no accident history.
Emergency Response Program
The facility has developed procedures for handling emergencies onsite and an offsite emergency response plan which has been reviewed and coordinated by the York County Local Emergency Planning Committee (YCEPC).  This program includes an emergency response decision tree and a notification plan.  Emergency response drills will be conducted with the fire companies, and the operation and response procedures will be reviewed and updated on a regular basis.
Planned Facilities to Improve Safety
The facility is new.  No safety improvements were identified during the hazard review.
